title: 104_hr4011
content: The "Congressional Pension Forfeiture Act of 1996" states that Members of Congress who breach the public trust should forfeit their retirement benefits, as taxpayers should not bear the cost for such actions. The "Congressional Pension Forfeiture Act of 1996" mandates that Members of Congress convicted of specific offenses while in office will not have their service counted for retirement benefits under the Civil Service Retirement System. They are entitled to receive their lump-sum credit for the service not considered. The "Congressional Pension Forfeiture Act of 1996" stipulates that Members of Congress convicted of certain offenses related to their service will not receive retirement benefits under the Civil Service Retirement System. The offenses must occur during the One Hundred Fifth Congress or later and include bribery, compensation, and practice restrictions outlined in specific sections of title 18. The "Congressional Pension Forfeiture Act of 1996" specifies that Members of Congress convicted of offenses related to their service will lose retirement benefits under the Civil Service Retirement System. The offenses must occur during the One Hundred Fifth Congress or later and include bribery, compensation, and practice restrictions outlined in specific sections of title 18, such as conspiracy, fraud, and influencing voting. The "Congressional Pension Forfeiture Act of 1996" states that Members of Congress convicted of certain offenses related to their service will lose retirement benefits under the Civil Service Retirement System. The offenses include bribery, compensation, and practice restrictions outlined in specific sections of title 18, such as conspiracy, fraud, and influencing voting. The "Congressional Pension Forfeiture Act of 1996" specifies that Members of Congress convicted of offenses like bribery, fraud, and perjury related to their service will forfeit retirement benefits under the Civil Service Retirement System. This includes offenses under various sections of title 18, such as interference with commerce, racketeering, prohibited activities, and tax evasion. The Act specifies that individuals convicted of certain offenses will lose retirement benefits under the Civil Service Retirement System. Regulations will be prescribed to enforce this, including limitations on interest payments and the return of vested amounts in the Thrift Savings Plan. The Act specifies that individuals convicted of certain offenses will lose retirement benefits under the Civil Service Retirement System. Regulations will be prescribed to enforce this, including limitations on interest payments and the return of vested amounts in the Thrift Savings Plan. Additionally, the amendment to Section 8411 of title 5, United States Code, states that the service of an individual convicted of specified offenses will not be considered for retirement benefits under the Federal Employees' Retirement System. The Act specifies that individuals convicted of certain offenses will lose retirement benefits under the Civil Service Retirement System. Regulations will be prescribed to enforce this, including limitations on interest payments and the return of vested amounts in the Thrift Savings Plan. Additionally, individuals convicted of specific offenses described in Section 8332(o)(2)(B) while serving as a Member during the One Hundred Fifth Congress or later will be ineligible for retirement benefits under this chapter. The Executive Director will prescribe regulations for the Thrift Savings Plan, including the return of vested amounts. No restrictions on denying benefits under other laws. The term 'Member' is defined as per section 2106. The House of Representatives passed the bill on September 26, 1996. Attest: ROBIN H. CARLE, Clerk.
